item.shortDesc: The macStyle italic bit is set, but the post table italic angle is zero
item.problem: The setting of the macStyle italic bit indicates the font is italic, but the italicAngle field in the post table suggests the font is upright. Correct these encodings using a table editing tool.

item.shortDesc: The magic number is not 0x5f0f3cf5
item.problem: 0x5f0f3cf5 is the specified value for the magicNumber.

item.shortDesc: The modified time is not valid
item.problem: The time the font was created should be a 64-bit integer that equals the number of seconds since midnight, January 1, 1904. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: Table length is not 54 bytes
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The table version number is not 0x00010000
item.problem: Version 0x00010000 is the only version of the hhea table currently defined. Correct this field using a table editing tool.

item.shortDesc: The unitsPerEm is greater than 16384
item.problem: The allowable range for the unitsPerEm value of a font is 16 - 16384 (for Windows) and 64 - 16384 (for Macintosh). For performance reasons, it is preferable to use a value that is a power of 2.

item.shortDesc: The unitsPerEm is less than 16
item.problem: The allowable range for the unitsPerEm value of a font is 16 - 16384 (for Windows) and 64 - 16384 (for Macintosh). For performance reasons, it is preferable to use a value that is a power of 2.

item.shortDesc: The xMax value does not match the maximum glyph xMax
item.problem:
The bounding box values should be computed using only glyphs that have contours. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored when identifying max and min values.

This error may indicate that the font is corrupted, or that the head table in the font was not updated after additional glyphs were added and the font should be regenerated.

item.shortDesc: The xMin value does not match the minimum glyph xMin
item.problem:
The bounding box values should be computed using only glyphs that have contours. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored when identifying max and min values.

This error may indicate that the font is corrupted, or that the head table in the font was not updated after additional glyphs were added and the font should be regenerated.

item.shortDesc: xMin is greater than xMax
item.problem:
The bounding box values should be computed using only glyphs that have contours. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored when identifying max and min values.

This error may indicate that the font is corrupted and must be regenerated using a font building tool.

item.shortDesc: The yMax value does not match the maximum glyph yMax
item.problem: This value should represent the extreme of all the glyphs in the font. Correct this value using a table editing tool or a tool that creates valid head tables.

item.shortDesc: The yMin value does not match the minimum glyph yMin
item.problem: This value should represent the extreme of all the glyphs in the font. Correct this value using a table editing tool or a tool that creates valid head tables.

item.shortDesc: yMin is greater than yMax
item.problem:
The bounding box values should be computed using only glyphs that have contours. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored when identifying max and min values.

This error may indicate that the font is corrupted and must be regenerated using a font building tool.

item.shortDesc: The advanceWidthMax field does not equal the calculated value
item.problem: The value of the advanceWidthMax field should equal the maximum advance width in stored in the hmtx table.

item.shortDesc: The metricDataFormat field is not set to zero
item.problem: Format 0 is the only currently defined format for the metricDataFormat.

item.shortDesc: The minLeftSideBearing field does not equal the calculated value
item.problem: The value of the minLeftSideBearing field should equal the minimum left side bearing value listed in the hmtx table for glyphs with contours. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored.

item.shortDesc: The minRightSideBearing field does not equal the calculated value
item.problem: The value of the minRightSideBearing field should equal Min(aw - lsb - (xMax - xMin)). Only glyphs with contours should be used when making this calculation. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored.

item.shortDesc: The numberOfHMetrics value is not consistent with the length of the hmtx table
item.problem:
The numberOfHMetrics field must have a value that reflects the number of HMetric entries in the hmtx table. An HMetric entry consists of paired advance width and left side bearing values for a glyph. If the font is monospaced, Microsoft recommends that there be three long-metric entries in the hmtx table, followed by the short metric (lsb) entries. The last long-metric entry in the hmtx table applies to all subsequent glyphs.

Ensure that the tool you are using is updating the value in the hhea table after compressing entries from long-metrics format to short-metrics.

item.shortDesc: Reserved field # 1 is non-zero
item.problem: This byte is reserved and should have a value of zero.

item.shortDesc: Reserved field # 2 is non-zero
item.problem: This byte is reserved and should have a value of zero.

item.shortDesc: Reserved field # 3 is non-zero
item.problem: This byte is reserved and should have a value of zero.

item.shortDesc: Reserved field # 4 is non-zero
item.problem: This byte is reserved and should have a value of zero.

item.shortDesc: The table version number is not 0x00010000
item.problem: Version 0x00010000 is the only version of the hhea table currently defined. Correct this field using a table editing tool.

item.shortDesc: The xMaxExtent field does not equal the calculated value
item.problem: The value of the xMaxExtent field should equal Max(lsb + (xMax - xMin)). This value should be computed using only glyphs that have contours. Glyphs with no contours should be ignored.

item.shortDesc: The caretSlopeRise/caretSlopeRun angle does not match the post.italicAngle
item.problem: The angle of the caret should equal the italicAngle of the font so that the insertion point nests well between glyphs. There are cases where these values will not be exactly equal, due to rounding -- but they should be as close as possible. Correct the italicAngle or the caretSlopeRise/Run values to be consistent.

item.shortDesc: The caretSlopeRun is nonzero, but the post.italicAngle is zero
item.problem: The angle of the caret should equal the italicAngle of the font so that the insertion point nests well between glyphs. There are cases where these values will not be exactly equal, due to rounding -- but they should be as close as possible. Correct the italicAngle or the caretSlopeRise/Run values to be consistent.

item.shortDesc: The caretSlopeRun is zero, but the post.italicAngle is nonzero
item.problem: The angle of the caret should equal the italicAngle of the font so that the insertion point nests well between glyphs. There are cases where these values will not be exactly equal, due to rounding -- but they should be as close as possible. Correct the italicAngle or the caretSlopeRise/Run values to be consistent.

item.shortDesc: The Ascender value must be greater than zero
item.problem: The Ascender value should be specified as a positive value, representing the distance above the baseline of the highest ascender. The ascender, descender, and linegap values are Apple specific.

item.shortDesc: The Descender value must be less than zero
item.problem: The Descender value should be specified as a negative value, representing the distance below the baseline of the lowest descender. The ascender, descender, and linegap values are Apple specific.

item.shortDesc: The size of the table does not match the calculated size
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The subtable's entrySelector value does not match the calculated value
item.problem: The entrySelector value, rangeShift value, and searchRange value are used to conduct an efficient binary search of the kerning list. The entrySelector value should equal log2(largest power of two<=the number of kerning pair entries).

item.shortDesc: The subtable's rangeShift value does not match the calculated value
item.problem: The entrySelector value, rangeShift value, and searchRange value are used to conduct an efficient binary search of the kerning list. The rangeShift value should equal (the number of kerning pair entries)-(largest power of 2<=(the number of kerning pair entries)*(size of an entry in bytes).

item.shortDesc: The subtable's searchRange value does not match the calculated value
item.problem: The entrySelector value, rangeShift value, and searchRange value are used to conduct an efficient binary search of the kerning list. The searchRange should equal the largest power of 2<=(the number of kerning pair entries)*(size of an entry in bytes).

item.shortDesc: The number of subtables is 0
item.problem: The kern table should contain a single kerning pair subtable, using format 0 or 2. Format 2 is not supported by Windows. If more than one subtable is used, Windows will only use the first format 0 subtable found.

item.shortDesc: A subtable has reserved coverage bits that are set
item.problem: Bits 4-7 of the coverage field are reserved and should all be set to 0.

item.shortDesc: A subtable was found which was not 0 or 2
item.problem: The kern table should contain a single kerning pair subtable, using either format 0 or format 2 (signifying two-dimensional array of kern values by class). Windows supports only format 0 of the kern table. Use a kern editing tool to properly create the kern table.

item.shortDesc: The subtable's length did not match the calculated length
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The table version was not 0
item.problem: Version 0 is the only version of the kern table currently defined. Correct this field using a table editing tool, or a kern editor that creates a valid kern table.

item.shortDesc: The subtable extends past the end of the table
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: A glyph id is invalid
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: The kerning value is invalid
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: A kern pair has a glyph ID that is not mapped in the cmap table
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: Incorrect format of loca
item.problem: There are two defined formats for the loca table: using short offsets (0) and using long offsets (1). This format value is stored in the head table in the indexToLocFormat field. This error will be reported if this field does not equal 0 or 1.

item.shortDesc: The number of entries is not equal (maxp.numGlyphs + 1)
item.problem:
The number of entries in the loca table should be the same as the number of glyphs specified in the maxp table, +1 (In order to compute the length of the last glyph element, there is an extra entry after the last valid index.)

Regenerate the loca table with an outline editing tool.

item.shortDesc: The entries are not sorted in ascending order
item.problem: The offsets to the locations of the glyphs in the font should be sorted in ascending order. These offset values are relative to the beginning of the glyphData table.

item.shortDesc: Loca entry points outside the glyf range
item.problem: There is an entry in the loca table that points outside the range(s) of glyf data. This may happen if the loca table has not been updated to reflect the removal of the final glyph(s) from a font.

item.shortDesc: The numGlyphs field does not equal maxp.numGlyphs
item.problem: Recreate the LTSH table so that the numGlyphs value equals the number of glyphs specified in the maxp table, and that there are yPel values defined for every glyph in the font. The yPel value specifies the ppem for each glyph at which the scaling becomes linear

item.shortDesc: The LTSH yPel values can't be validated due to an error while rasterizing the glyphs, likely a hinting instruction error
item.problem: Metrics affected by hints can only be validated at runtime. Therefore, this error is typically generated when the Font Validator uses the rasterizer to execute the hinting instructions contained in the font. The detail of this error message may or may not refer to the glyph that is associated with the bad hinting code, depending on how the overflow or other rasterizing error was encountered. For example, in the case of a stack overflow, the problem may be due to hinting instructions for a previous glyph not having been properly removed from the stack. To perform detailed checks of hinting instructions, select rasterization testing in the Font Validator, or use a tool such as Microsoft's Flint or VTT.

item.shortDesc: The calculated table length does not match the actual table length
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The version number is not 0
item.problem: Version 0 is the only version of the LTSH table currently defined. Correct this field using a table editing tool, or use a tool such as CacheTT that calculates LTSH values and creates this table properly.

item.shortDesc: The LTSH yPel value doesn't match the calculated value
item.problem: The yPel value, the ppem for each glyph at which the scaling becomes linear, does not match the value calculated by the current version of the rasterizer. These values may not match if the LTSH table was generated using a previous version of the rasterizer, or another tool that performs the yPel calculations differently. To make the values match, use the latest version of CacheTT to calculate the cached values using the current rasterizer. However, you may not want to change these values if there are concerns about the way text in legacy documents might reflow.

item.shortDesc: The value doesn't match the calculated value
item.problem: The discrepancy noted in this warning message can be corrected by a font hinting tool or font editing tool that automatically builds the maxp table. Although many of the maxp values will be blank in unhinted fonts, the full table is still required.

item.shortDesc: Table version is 0x00005000 but the table is not 6 bytes long
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: Table version is 1.0 but the table is not 32 bytes long
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The numGlyphs value doesn't match the number of entries in the loca array
item.problem:
The number of entries in the loca table should be the same as the number of glyphs specified in the maxp table, +1 (In order to compute the length of the last glyph element, there is an extra entry after the last valid index.)

Regenerate the loca table with an outline editing tool.

item.shortDesc: Table version is 0x00005000 but font contains a glyf table
item.problem: Version 0x00005000 of the maxp table is used only for fonts containing CFF data stored in the CFF table, not TrueType outlines stored in a glyf table. Either remove the CFF data in the font and change the version to 0x00010000, or remove the glyf table and keep the version number as is. Correct this field using a table editing tool. Note that Microsoft requires that only one outline format be stored in a font.

item.shortDesc: Table version is 0x00005000 but font does not contain the required CFF table
item.problem: Version 0x00005000 of the maxp table is used only for fonts containing CFF data stored in the CFF table, not TrueType outlines stored in a glyf table. Either add the CFF data in the font and leave the version number as is or change the version number to 0x00010000 to reflect the presence of the glyf table (with TrueType outlines). Correct this field using a table editing tool. Note that Microsoft requires that only one outline format be stored in a font.

item.shortDesc: Table version is 1.0 but font contains a CFF table
item.problem: Version 0x00010000 of the maxp table is used only for fonts containing TrueType outlines stored in a glyf table, not for fonts containing CFF data in a CFF table. Either remove the CFF data in the font and change and leave the version as is, or remove the glyf table and change the version number to 0x00005000. Correct this field using a table editing tool. Note that Microsoft requires that only one outline format be stored in a font.

item.shortDesc: Table version is 1.0 but font does not contain the required glyf table
item.problem: Version 0x00010000 of the maxp table is used only for fonts containing TrueType outlines stored in a glyf table, not for fonts containing CFF data in a CFF table. Either add a glyf table to the font and keep the version number as is, or change the version number to 0x00005000 to reflect the presence of CFF data in the font. Correct this field using a table editing tool. Note that Microsoft requires that only one outline format be stored in a font.

item.shortDesc: Table version must be either 0x00005000 or 0x00010000
item.problem: Version 0x00005000 and Version 0x00010000 are the only two versions of the maxp table currently defined. Version 0x00005000 indicates a font file containing CFF data stored in a CFF table; Version 0x00010000 indicates a font file containing TrueType outline data in a glyf table. Note that Microsoft requires that only one type of outline data be used in each font.

item.shortDesc: The format selector field is not 0
item.problem: 0 is the only specified value for the format field.

item.shortDesc: The Language ID is not valid
item.problem: The Locale (Language) ID used within one or more NameRecords is not a currently specified Locale ID. For a complete list of Locale ID's, see the Locale ID chart.

item.shortDesc: The NameRecords array is not in sorted order
item.problem: The NameRecords array must be sorted by platform ID, then platform-specific ID, then language ID, and then by name.

item.shortDesc: The table doesn't contain strings for Mac platform
item.problem: Name strings are required for both platforms. Use a table editing tool to add name strings for Windows.

item.shortDesc: The table doesn't contain strings for Microsoft platform
item.problem: Name strings are required for both platforms. Use a table editing tool to add name strings for Windows.

item.shortDesc: The Platform Specific Encoding ID is out of range
item.problem:
For Platform 0 (Unicode) the following Encoding ID's are valid:

Encoding ID Description
0 Unicode 1.0 semantics
1 Unicode 1.1 semantics
2 ISO 10646:1993 semantics
3 Unicode 2.0 and onwards semantics, Unicode BMP only.
4 Unicode 2.0 and onwards semantics, Unicode full repertoire.


For Platform 3 (Microsoft) the following Encoding ID's are valid:

Platform ID Encoding ID Description
3 0 Symbol
3 1 Unicode BMP only
3 2 ShiftJIS
3 3 PRC
3 4 Big5
3 5 Wansung
3 6 Johab
3 7 Reserved
3 8 Reserved
3 9 Reserved
3 10 Unicode full repertoire

item.shortDesc: The PostScript string contains an illegal character
item.problem: When translated to ASCII, this name string must contain only characters that are in the printable ASCII subset, codes 33 through 126, except for the 10 characters: '[', ']', '(', ')', '{', '}', '<', '>', '/', '%'.

item.shortDesc: The PostScript string is longer than 63 characters
item.problem: The PostScript name strings may not be longer than 63 characters.

item.shortDesc: The PostScript string is not present for both required platforms
item.problem: OpenType fonts that include a PostScript name for the font must include names for Platform 1 Encoding 0 (Mac) and Platform 3 Encoding 1 (Microsoft)

item.shortDesc: The Mac PostScript string does not match the Microsoft PostScript string
item.problem:
OpenType fonts which include a PostScript name (name ID 6) should include both Microsoft and Macintosh PostScript names, as follows:

Platform: 1 [Macintosh]; Platform-specific encoding: 0 [Roman]; Language: 0 [English].

Platform: 3 [Microsoft]; Platform-specific encoding: 1 [Unicode]; Language: 0x409 [English (American)].

When translated to ASCII, these two name strings must be identical; no longer than 63 characters; and restricted to the printable ASCII subset, codes 33 through 126, except for the 10 characters: '[', ']', '(', ')', '{', '}', '<', '>', '/', '%'.

item.shortDesc: A name record is using a reserved Name ID
item.problem: Name ID's 0-20 are pre-defined; Name ID's 21-255, inclusive, are reserved for future standard names; Name ID's 256-32767, inclusive, are reserved for font-specific names such as those referenced by a font's layout features.

item.shortDesc: A string extends past the end of the table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The length of the unicode string is not an even # of bytes
item.problem: Check that the Platform ID is correctly specified for this name record, or recreate the record using double-byte unicode values.

item.shortDesc: The version string is not formatted correctly
item.problem: The version string must contain a number in the following form: one or more digits (0-9) of value less than 65,535, followed by a period, followed by one or more digits of value less than 65,535. Any character other than a digit will terminate the minor number. A character such as ";" is helpful to delineate the number from additional pieces of version information. The first version number listed in the string as noted can be used by installation software to compare font versions. Note that some installers may require the string to start with the word "Version" followed by a space and then the version number as above.

item.shortDesc: No Microsoft unicode version strings were found
item.problem: Name strings are required for both platforms. Use a table editing tool to add name strings for Windows.

item.shortDesc: The sample string contains a character that is not mapped in the font
item.problem: All characters in the sample string must exist in the font. Remove the non-existent character from the sample string.

item.shortDesc: A bit in the fsSelection field doesn't match the name table's font subfamily string
item.problem:
There are several places within the font file that the typeface may be characterized as 'Regular,' 'Bold,' 'Italic,' 'Condensed,' etc. Font designers should encode this information consistently throughout the font. Font clients use the information to:
  • organize related typefaces into families (i.e., Arial Narrow, Arial, Arial Bold, Arial Expanded...)
  • use appropriate names when enumerating typefaces to the user
  • obtain a font from the system according to certain attributes (weight, style, width)
The fields related to encoding this information exist in several different tables:
  • In the name table, Name ID strings (family name, subfamily name, full-font name, preferred family grouping, and preferred subfamily grouping)
  • In the OS/2 table, usWeightClass, usWidthClass, fsSelection, and PANOSE(tm)
  • In the head table, macStyle bits
Correct this data using a table editing tool.
For examples of how to use these various fields, see these name string examples.

item.shortDesc: There are undefined bits set in fsSelection field
item.problem: Of the 2-byte fsSelection field, only bits 0-6 are defined. All remaining undefined bits must be set to 0.

item.shortDesc: The fsType field contains reserved bits that are not zero
item.problem: Bits 0, 4-7, and 10-15 of the fsType field are reserved and must be set to 0.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 7, ArmStyle > 11
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that want to substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 5, Contrast > 9
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 1, FamilyType > 5
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 8, Letterform > 15
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 9, Midline > 13
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 4, Proportion > 9
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 2, SerifStyle > 15
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 6, StrokeVariation > 10
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 3, Weight > 11
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) byte 10, XHeight > 7
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not reliably available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: A unicode range was indicated in ulUnicodeRange, but the font has no characters in that range
item.problem: This error may appear if an incorrect unicode range bit was set, or if there has been a change to the characters within the font after the range bit was set. Use a table-editing tool to change the ulUnicodeRange value to reflect the character coverage of the font.

item.shortDesc: The fsSelection field has both the Regular and Bold bits set
item.problem: If bit 6 is set, indicating standard weight/style for the font, then bits 0-5 must be clear. Otherwise, the behavior of the font is undefined.

item.shortDesc: The fsSelection field has both the Regular and Italic bits set
item.problem: If bit 6 is set, indicating standard weight/style for the font, then bits 0-5 must be clear. Otherwise, the behavior of the font is undefined.

item.shortDesc: A reserved bit is set in a ulCodePageRange field
item.problem: The following bits in the ulCodePageRange field are reserved and must be set to 0: bits 9-15, 22-28, 32-47

item.shortDesc: A reserved bit is set in a ulUnicodeRange field
item.problem: The following bits in the ulUnicodeRange field are reserved and must be set to 0: bits 8, 12, 14, 27, 58, 84-127.

item.shortDesc: The sCapHeight field is zero, but the U+0048 character is mapped to a glyf
item.problem:
This sCapHeight field should specify the distance between the baseline and the approximate height of uppercase letters measured in FUnits. This value would normally be specified by a type designer but in situations where that is not possible, for example when a legacy font is being converted, the value may be set equal to the top of the unscaled and unhinted glyph bounding box of the glyph encoded at U+0048 (LATIN CAPITAL LETTER H).

The field should be set to 0 only if no glyph is encoded in this position.

item.shortDesc: sFamilyClass class ID is reserved
item.problem: Class ID's 6, 11, 13, and 14 are reserved for future use.

item.shortDesc: sFamilyClass class ID is undefined
item.problem:
Only Family Class ID's 0 through 14 are defined (with several of those reserved).

The font class and font subclass are registered values assigned by IBM to each font family. This parameter is intended for use in selecting an alternate font when the requested font is not available. The font class is the most general and the font subclass is the most specific.

item.shortDesc: sFamilyClass subclass ID is undefined
item.problem:
Defined, non-reserved family classes only have subclasses with defined values of 0-15 (with some of those subclasses being reserved).

The font class and font subclass are registered values assigned by IBM to each font family. This parameter is intended for use in selecting an alternate font when the requested font is not available. The font class is the most general and the font subclass is the most specific.

item.shortDesc: The surrogates bit (bit #57) is clear in the ulUnicodeRange, but the cmap contains a surrogates encoding
item.problem: The surrogates bit should be set if there is at least one codepoint beyond the Basic Multilingual Plane that is supported by the font.

item.shortDesc: The surrogates bit (bit #57) is set in the ulUnicodeRange, but the cmap doesn't contain a surrogates encoding
item.problem: Setting the surrogates bit implies that there is at least one codepoint beyond the Basic Multilingual Plane that is supported by this font.

item.shortDesc: The sxHeight field is zero, but the U+0078 character is mapped to a glyf
item.problem: If a glyph is encoded in the position of U+0078 (LATIN SMALL LETTER X), then the sxHeight field should be set equal to the top of the unscaled and unhinted glyph bounding box of the glyph (in FUnits).

item.shortDesc: The font contains a 3,0 cmap, but the CodePageRange bit #31 (symbol character set) is clear
item.problem:
The CodePageRange bits are used to specify the code pages encompassed by the font file in the 'cmap' subtable for platform 3, encoding ID 1 (Microsoft platform). If the font file is encoding ID 0, then the Symbol Character Set bit (31) should be set.

If the symbol bit is set, and the font file contains a 'cmap' subtable for platform of 3 and encoding ID of 1, then all of the characters in the Unicode range 0xF000 - 0xF0FF (inclusive) will be used to enumerate the symbol character set. If the bit is not set, any characters present in that range will not be enumerated as a symbol character set.

item.shortDesc: The font doesn't contain a 3,0 cmap and doesn't contain characters mapped to the 0xf000-0xf0ff range, but the CodePageRange bit #31 (symbol character set) is set
item.problem: If the symbol bit is set, and the font file contains a 'cmap' subtable for platform of 3 and encoding ID of 1, then all of the characters in the Unicode range 0xF000 - 0xF0FF (inclusive) will be used to enumerate the symbol character set. If the bit is not set, any characters present in that range will not be enumerated as a symbol character set.

item.shortDesc: The table length does not match the expected length for this version
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The usBreakChar is not mapped to a glyf
item.problem: The break character is used to separate words and justify text. Most fonts specify 'space' as the break character.

item.shortDesc: The usDefaultChar field is nonzero, but the character is not mapped to a glyf
item.problem: Whenever a request is made for a character that is not in the font, Windows provides this default character. If the value of this field is zero, glyph ID 0 is to be used for the default character. If the value of this field is non-zero, then the value of the field indicates the Unicode encoding of the glyph that Windows uses as the default character. This specified glyph must exist in the font.

item.shortDesc: The usFirstCharIndex is not valid
item.problem: The minimum Unicode index (character code) in this font, according to the cmap subtable for platform ID 3 and platform- specific encoding ID 0 or 1. For most fonts supporting Win-ANSI or other character sets, this value would be 0x0020. This field cannot represent supplementary character values (codepoints greater than 0xFFFF). Fonts that support supplementary characters should set the value in this field to 0xFFFF if the minimum index value is a supplementary character.

item.shortDesc: The usLastCharIndex is not valid
item.problem: The maximum Unicode index (character code) in this font, according to the cmap subtable for platform ID 3 and encoding ID 0 or 1. This value depends on which character sets the font supports. This field cannot represent supplementary character values (codepoints greater than 0xFFFF). Fonts that support supplementary characters should set the value in this field to 0xFFFF.

item.shortDesc: The version number is invalid
item.problem: The current version of the OS/2 table is Version 3. Versions zero (0, TrueType rev 1.5), one (1, TrueType rev 1.66), and two (2, OpenType rev 1.2) have been used previously.

item.shortDesc: The usWeightClass is not a valid value
item.problem:
The usWeightClass field indicates the visual weight of the characters in the font. Values may range from 100 (Thin) to 900 (Black), in increments of 100. The usWeightClass is used by the system to obtain a font when an application requests a font with a specified weight class (through the CreateFont API).
There are several places within the font file that the typeface may be characterized as 'Regular,' 'Bold,' 'Italic,' 'Condensed,' etc. Font designers should encode this information consistently throughout the font. Font clients use the information to:
  • organize related typefaces into families (i.e., Arial Narrow, Arial, Arial Bold, Arial Expanded...)
  • use appropriate names when enumerating typefaces to the user
  • obtain a font from the system according to certain attributes (weight, style, width)
The fields related to encoding this information exist in several different tables:
  • In the name table, Name ID strings (family name, subfamily name, full-font name, preferred family grouping, and preferred subfamily grouping)
  • In the OS/2 table, usWeightClass, usWidthClass, fsSelection, and PANOSE(tm)
  • In the head table, macStyle bits
Correct this data using a table editing tool.
For examples of how to use these various fields, see these name string examples.

item.shortDesc: The width class is not a valid value
item.problem:
The usWidthClass field indicates the relative change from the normal aspect ratio for the glyphs in a font. Values range from 1 (Ultra-condensed or 50% of normal) to 9 (Ultra-expanded or 200% of normal). The usWidthClass is used by the system to obtain a font when an application requests a font with a specified width class (through the CreateFont API).
There are several places within the font file that the typeface may be characterized as 'Regular,' 'Bold,' 'Italic,' 'Condensed,' etc. Font designers should encode this information consistently throughout the font. Font clients use the information to:
  • organize related typefaces into families (i.e., Arial Narrow, Arial, Arial Bold, Arial Expanded...)
  • use appropriate names when enumerating typefaces to the user
  • obtain a font from the system according to certain attributes (weight, style, width)
The fields related to encoding this information exist in several different tables:
  • In the name table, Name ID strings (family name, subfamily name, full-font name, preferred family grouping, and preferred subfamily grouping)
  • In the OS/2 table, usWeightClass, usWidthClass, fsSelection, and PANOSE(tm)
  • In the head table, macStyle bits
Correct this data using a table editing tool.
For examples of how to use these various fields, see these name string examples.

item.shortDesc: The xAvgCharWidth field does not equal the calculated value
item.problem: The xAvgCharWidth value for non-symbol fonts specifies the arithmetic average of the width of all the non-zero width glyphs in a font (change per spec version 1.4). For symbol fonts, the xAvgCharWidth should be calculated as the unweighted average of all mapped glyphs, including those with null contours.

item.shortDesc: Font is a symbol font, but PANOSE(tm) byte 1, FamilyType, is not set to Latin Symbol
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: Font is a not a symbol font, but PANOSE(tm) byte 1, FamilyType, is set to Latin Symbol
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE family kind is Latin Symbol, but byte 5, Aspect Ratio and Contrast, does not equal 1
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE family kind is Latin Symbol, but byte 3, Weight, does not equal 1
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: The fsSelection bold bit is inconsistent with the macStyle bold bit
item.problem: Use a table editing tool to correct either the fsSelection bold bit (bit 5) in the OS/2 table, or the macStyle bold bit (bit 0) in the head table.

item.shortDesc: The fsSelection italic bit is inconsistent with the macStyle italic bit
item.problem: Use a table editing tool to correct either the fsSelection italic bit (bit 0) in the OS/2 table, or the macStyle italic bit (bit 1) in the head table.

item.shortDesc: The sTypoAscender value is less than or equal to zero
item.problem: The sTypoAscender value is used to determine the optimum offset from the top of a text frame to the first baseline. The sTypoDescender value should be greater than zero, and the value of (sTypoAscender - sTypoDescender) is recommended to equal one em. To learn more about this value, see the Recommendations for OpenType Fonts.

item.shortDesc: The sTypoDescender value is greater than zero
item.problem: The sTypoDescender value is used to determine the optimum offset from the last baseline to the bottom of the text frame. The sTypoDescender value should be negative, and the value of (sTypoAscender - sTypoDescender) is recommended to equal one em. To learn more about this value, see the Recommendations for OpenType Fonts.

item.shortDesc: The fsType field has mutually exclusive bits set
item.problem:
The following bits are mutually exclusive:
0x0002, Restricted License embedding
0x0004, Preview and Print embedding
0x0008, Editable embedding

item.shortDesc: The usMaxContext field doesn't match the calculated value
item.problem: This field should represent the maximum length of a target glyph context for any feature in the font. For example, if the font has a ligature feature in which the glyph sequence 'f f i' is substituted by the ligature 'ffi', then this field should be set to 3. For chaining contextual lookups, the length of the string (covered glyph) + (input sequence) + (lookahead sequence) should be considered.

item.shortDesc: The SerifStyle bottom 6 bit value is invalid
item.problem:
The SerifStyle bottom 6 bit values may equal the following. Correct this value using a table editing tool.
0 Sans Serif Square
1 Sans Serif Round
2 Serif Line
3 Serif Triangle
4 Serif Swath
5 Serif Block
6 Serif Bracket
7 Rounded Bracket
8 Flair Serif, Modified Sans
9 Script Nonconnecting
10 Script Joining
11 Script Calligraphic
12 Script Broken Letter

item.shortDesc: The Pitch field does not equal the width of the space character
item.problem: The Pitch value in the PCLT table should be the same as the space character in FUnits (as described by the unitsPerEm field of the 'head' table).

item.shortDesc: The Reserved field is not zero
item.problem: The last byte of the PCLT table is reserved for padding, and should be set to zero.

item.shortDesc: The StrokeWeight value was not in the range of -7 to 7
item.problem: For the StrokeWeight field, only values in the range of -7 (Ultra Thin) to 7 (Ultra Black) are valid.

item.shortDesc: The Style Posture bits have a reserved value of 3
item.problem: Bits 0-1 of the Style field are used to encode Posture, with the values signifying: 0 - upright; 1 - italic/oblique; 2 - alternate italic. These bits should not be set to indicate a value of 3, as this value is reserved.

item.shortDesc: The Style field has non zero bits in the most significant 6 bits
item.problem: The most significant 6 bits of the Style field are reserved and must indicate a value of zero.

item.shortDesc: The Style Structure bits are in the reserved range of 18 to 31
item.problem: Bits 5-9 of the Style field are used to encode Structure. Only values 0-17 may be encoded in these bits; values 18-31 are reserved.

item.shortDesc: The Style Width bits have a reserved value of 5
item.problem: Bits 2-4 of the Style field are used to encode Width. With the exception of reserved value 5, these bits may be used to encode values 0-7.

item.shortDesc: The table length is not 54 bytes
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The SerifStyle top 2 bit value is invalid
item.problem:
The most significant two bits of the serifStyle byte specify the serif/sans or contrast/monoline characterisitics of the typeface. The bits may have the following values:
0 reserved
1 Sans Serif/Monoline
2 Serif/Contrasting
3 reserved

item.shortDesc: The version is not 0x00010000
item.problem: Version 0x00010000 is currently the only defined version of the PCLT table.

item.shortDesc: The WidthType value was not in the range of -5 to 5
item.problem: For the WidthType field, only values in the range -5 (Ultra Compressed) to 5 (Extra Expanded) are valid.

item.shortDesc: An entry in the glyphNameIndex - 258 is greater than the number of names
item.problem: The glyphNameIndex field should contain a value indicating the ordinal number of the glyph in the post string tables. For values in the range of 258-32767, the number of strings in the post table should equal (glyphNameIndex - 258). Regenerate this font.

item.shortDesc: The table length is invalid
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The isFixedPitch field is nonzero, but hmtx shows the font as proportional
item.problem: Ensure that the designation of fixed-pitch within the font is consistent. Currently, the value for the isFixedPitch in the post table indicates that the font is monospaced, but there are multiple pairs of advance width/left side bearing values in the hmtx table (indicating the font is not fixed pitch). Use a table editing tool to correct value of the isFixedPitch field, or remove all but one pair of metric data from the hmtx table.

item.shortDesc: The isFixedPitch field != 0, but the OS/2 panose bProportion is not monospace
item.problem: Ensure that the designation of fixed-pitch within the font is consistent. Currently, the value for the isFixedPitch in the post table indicates that the font is monospaced, but the PANOSE bProportion field in the OS/2 table indicates that the font is not monospaced. Use a table editing tool to correct values of the isFixedPitch field and the bProportion field so that they agree.

item.shortDesc: The isFixedPitch field is zero, but hmtx shows the font as fixed pitch
item.problem: Ensure that the designation of fixed-pitch within the font is consistent. Currently, the value for the isFixedPitch in the post table indicates that the font is not monospaced, but there is only one pair of advance width/left side bearing values in the hmtx table (indicating the font is fixed pitch). Use a table editing tool to correct value of the isFixedPitch field, or fully populate the hmtx table with metric data.

item.shortDesc: The isFixedPitch field is zero, but the OS/2 panose bProportion is monospace
item.problem: Ensure that the designation of fixed-pitch within the font is consistent. Currently, the value for the isFixedPitch in the post table indicates that the font is not monospaced, but the PANOSE bProportion field in the OS/2 table indicates that the font is monospaced. Use a table editing tool to correct values of the isFixedPitch field and the bProportion field so that they agree.

item.shortDesc: The italicAngle is nonzero, but the hhea.caretSlopeRun is zero
item.problem: The current setting of the caretSlopeRun in the hhea table suggests that the font is upright, but the italicAngle value in the post table indicates an italic font. Ensure that italic designation is consistent within the font by making the italicAngle zero, or by setting the caretSlopeRun value in the hhea table to non-zero.

item.shortDesc: The italicAngle does not match the hhea.caretSlopeRise/hhea.caretSlopeRun angle
item.problem: The angle of the caret should equal the italicAngle of the font so that the insertion point nests well between glyphs. There are cases where these values will not be exactly equal, due to rounding -- but they should be as close as possible. Correct the italicAngle or the caretSlopeRise/Run values to be consistent.

item.shortDesc: The italicAngle is nonzero, but the head.macStyle italic bit is not set
item.problem:
Ensure that italic designation is consistent within the font. One case where these designations may differ is in the encoding of a font that has a slope, such as a script face. Such a font will have the italicAngle set, but since it is not considered italic within its own family, the italic bit may not be set.

Use a table editing tool to set the macStyle italic bit (bit 1), or enter zero for the italicAngle in the post table to indicate the font is upright.

item.shortDesc: The italicAngle is zero, but the hhea.caretSlopeRun is not zero
item.problem: The current setting of the caretSlopeRun in the hhea table suggests that the font is italic, but the italicAngle value in the post table indicates an upright font. Ensure that italic designation is consistent within the font by making the italicAngle non-zero, or by setting the caretSlopeRun value in the hhea table to zero.

item.shortDesc: The italicAngle is zero, but the head.macStyle italic bit is set
item.problem: Ensure that italic designation is consistent within the font. Use a table editing tool to clear the macStyle italic bit (bit 1), or enter a non-zero value for the italicAngle in the post table (negative for text that leans to the right).

item.shortDesc: The table length is not 32 bytes long
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The post name extends past the end of the table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The offset to the post name is invalid
item.problem: In version 2.0 of the post table, the offset to post names is derived from the glyphNameIndex. Although the index for this glyph may be valid, the offset points outside the post table (compared with the size of the post table as defined in the font file header). Recreate the post table.

item.shortDesc: The numberOfGlyphs field does not equal maxp.numGlyphs
item.problem: The numberOfGlyphs field should be the same as the numGlyphs field in the maxp table.

item.shortDesc: The version number is invalid
item.problem: The post table has four possible versions: version 1.0 (TrueType-based font file containing 258 glyphs in the standard Macintosh set); version 2.0 (TrueType-based font file, version 2.5 (deprecated as of OpenType Specification v1.3), and version 3.0, used by OpenType fonts with TrueType or CFF data.

item.shortDesc: The VDMX data doesn't match the data calculated by the rasterizer
item.problem: The VDMX data does not match the value calculated by the current version of the rasterizer. This data may not match if glyphs have been updated but the VDMX table has not been recalculated (using a tool such as Microsoft's CacheTT). The problem may also occur if the VDMX table was generated using a previous version of the rasterizer, or another tool that performs the calculations differently. To correct the data, use the latest version of CacheTT to calculate the cached values using the current rasterizer. However, you may not want to change these values if there are concerns about the way text in legacy documents might reflow.

item.shortDesc: A VDMX group isn't within the table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: An offset to a VDMX group is invalid
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The version number is not 0 or 1
item.problem: There are currently only two versions of the VDMX table defined: 0 and 1. Microsoft recommends using version 1 of the VDMX table.

item.shortDesc: The yPelHeight value is greater than 255
item.problem: YPel Height values in the VDMX table must be in the range of 0..255.

item.shortDesc: The metricDataFormat field is not set to zero
item.problem: Zero is the only allowed value for the metricDataFormat. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: The reserved fields are not all set to zero
item.problem: All reserved fields in the vhea table must be set to 0.

item.shortDesc: The version is not valid
item.problem:
Two versions of the vhea table are currently defined:

Version 1.0 (0x00010000) defines ascent as the distance from the centerline to the previous line's descent; descent as the distance from the centerline to the next line's ascent; and lineGap as reserved (0).

Version 1.1 (0x00011000, note the representation of a non-zero fractional part in Fixed numbers) defines vertTypoAscender, vertTypoDescender, and vertTypoLineGap as functions of the ideographic em-box.

item.shortDesc: The table length is incorrect
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The font is not a CFF font, and so it should not contain a VORG table
item.problem: The VORG table improves accuracy and efficiency for font clients of CFF OpenType fonts. For fonts that contain TrueType outline data, the VORG table will be ignored.

item.shortDesc: The major.minor version is not 1.0
item.problem: The majorVersion value of the specified VORG format is 1. The minorVersion value of the specified VORG format is 0.

item.shortDesc: The AttachPoint array extends past the end of the GDEF table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The AttachPoint offset points outside of the GDEF table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The Coverage offset is zero
item.problem: This value should specify the offset to the Coverage table listing all the glyphs that define attachment points in the GPOS table. The offset is calculated from the beginning of the AttachList table.

item.shortDesc: The Coverage offset points past the end of the GDEF table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The CaretValueFormat is invalid
item.problem:
The CaretValueTable can have the following formats:

Format 1 consists of a format identifier, followed by a single coordinate for the caret position.

Format 2 specifies the caret coordinate in terms of a contour point index on a specific glyph.

Format 3 also specifies the value in design units, but uses a Device table rather than a contour point to adjust the value.

item.shortDesc: The Coverage offset is zero
item.problem: This value should specify the offset to the Coverage table listing all the ligature glyphs in the font. The offset is calculated from the beginning of the LigCaretList table.

item.shortDesc: The Coverage offset points past the end of the GDEF table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The LigGlyph array extends past the end of the GDEF table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. Structural errors may be caused by: a font tool incorrectly generating the font file; a person altering the contents of a valid font file; or some other corruption to the font file. Regenerate the font, or contact the font vendor to obtain a valid version of the font.

item.shortDesc: The LigGlyph offset points outside of the GDEF table

item.shortDesc: The AnchorFormat field is invalid
item.problem:
The Anchor table has the following defined formats:

Format 1 consists of a format identifier and a pair of design unit coordinates that specify the location of the anchor point.

Format 2 specifies a format identifier, a pair of design unit coordinates for the anchor point, and an index to a glyph contour point that is on the outline of a glyph.

Format 3 specifies a format identifier, locates an anchor point, and permits fine adjustments to the coordinate values via Device tables (rather than a contour point).

item.shortDesc: The extension lookup type is invalid
item.problem:
The ExtensionLookupType field must be set to one of the defined lookup types, excluding lookup type 9 (1-8 are valid). All subtables in a LookupType 9 lookup must have the same ExtensionLookupType.

Use an OpenType Layout editing tool to create properly structured tables, or regenerate the font if you believe it may have become corrupted

item.shortDesc: The array order is incorrect
item.problem:
Use an OpenType Layout editing tool to create properly structured tables, or regenerate the font if you believe it may have become corrupted. Some of the GPOS arrays and their orderings are listed below:

PairSetOffsets - ordered by Coverage index
PairValueRecords - ordered by GlyphID of the second glyph
Class1Records - ordered by Class1 value
Class2Records - ordered by Class2 value
BaseRecords - ordered by BaseCoverage index
BaseAnchors - ordered by Class
LigatureAttachOffsets - ordered by LigatureCoverage index
ComponentRecords - ordered in writing direction
LigatureAnchors - ordered by Class
Mark2Records - ordered by Coverage
PosRuleSets - ordered by Coverage
PosRules - ordered by preference
PosLookupRecords - ordered by design order
PosClassSets - ordered by Class
PosClassRules - ordered by preference

item.problem: This table may not be constructed properly, or the offset value has been set or changed incorrectly. The BaseScriptListOffset should indicate the offset to the BaseScriptList table from the beginning of the Axis table.

item.shortDesc: The Axis Table's BaseTagListOffset is outside the BASE table
item.problem: This error indicates a structural problem with the font. item.shortDesc: The format of the BaseCoord table is not a valid value
item.problem:
Use a table editing tool to correct this value, or recreate the BASE table using valid formats for the BaseCoord tables. There are currently three formats for the BaseCoord table:

Format 1 consists of a format identifier, followed by a single design unit coordinate that specifies the BaseCoord value. This format has the benefits of small size and simplicity, but the BaseCoord value cannot be hinted for fine adjustments at different sizes or device resolutions.

Format 2 specifies the BaseCoord value in design units, but also supplies a glyph index and a contour point for reference. During font hinting, the contour point on the glyph outline may move.

Format 3 specifies the BaseCoord value in design units, but it uses a Device table rather than a contour point to adjust the value.

item.shortDesc: The BaseTagList table contains an invalid tag
item.problem:
All tag names consist of four characters. Names with less than four characters are allowed if followed by the necessary trailing spaces. All tag names defined within a font (including table names, feature tags, and language tags) must be composed of printing characters represented by ASCII values 32-126.

The Baseline Tags section of the OpenType Tag Registry lists currently registered baseline tags. To learn more about registered tags, see the OpenType Tag Registry

item.shortDesc: A BaseCoord offset in the BaseValues table is zero
item.problem: Offsets to each BaseCoord table (from the beginning of the BaseValues table) are stored within the BaseValues table. The order of the stored offsets corresponds to the order of the tags listed in the BaselineTag array of the BaseTagList. In other words, the first position in the BaseCoord array will define the offset to the BaseCoord table for the first baseline named in the BaselineTag array, the second position will define the offset to the BaseCoord table for the second baseline named in the BaselineTag array, and so on.

item.problem:
The ClassDef table can have either of two formats:

Format 1 assigns a range of consecutive glyph indices to different classes.

Format 2 puts groups of consecutive glyph indices into the same class.

item.shortDesc: The RangeRecord array is not in sorted order
item.problem: Each RangeRecord consists of a start glyph index (Start), an end glyph index (End), and the Coverage Index associated with the range's Start glyph. Ranges must be in starting GlyphID order, and they must be distinct, with no overlapping.

item.shortDesc: The RangeRecord array extends past the end of the table

item.shortDesc: The Format field is invalid
item.problem:
There are two formats for Coverage tables:

Coverage Format 1 consists of a count of covered glyphs (GlyphCount), followed by an array of glyph indices (GlyphArray). The glyph indices must be in numerical order for binary searching of the list.

Coverage Format 2 consists of a count of glyph index ranges (RangeCount), followed by an array of records (RangeRecords). Each RangeRecord consists of a start glyph index (Start), an end glyph index (End), and the Coverage Index associated with the range's Start glyph. Ranges must be in GlyphID order, and they must be distinct, with no overlapping.

item.shortDesc: The LookupFlag reserved bits are not all set to zero

item.shortDesc: The LookupType value is invalid
item.problem:
OpenType Layout has seven types of GSUB lookups and nine types of GPOS lookups.


LookupType Enumeration table for glyph substitution

Value Type Description
1 Single Replace one glyph with one glyph
2 Multiple Replace one glyph with more than one glyph
3 Alternate Replace one glyph with one of many glyphs
4 Ligature Replace multiple glyphs with one glyph
5 Context Replace one or more glyphs in context
6 Chaining Context Replace one or more glyphs in chained context
7 Extension Substitution Extension mechanism for other substitutions (i.e. this excludes the Extension type substitution itself)
8 Reverse chaining context single Applied in reverse order, replace single glyph in chaining context
9+ Reserved For future use


LookupType Enumeration table for glyph positioning

Value Type Description
1 Single adjustment Adjust position of a single glyph
2 Pair adjustment Adjust position of a pair of glyphs
3 Cursive attachment Attach cursive glyphs
4 MarkToBase attachment Attach a combining mark to a base glyph
5 MarkToLigature attachment Attach a combining mark to a ligature
6 MarkToMark attachment Attach a combining mark to another mark
7 Context positioning Position one or more glyphs in context
8 Chained Context positioning Position one or more glyphs in chained context
9 Extension positioning Extension mechanism for other positionings
10+ Reserved For future use


To learn more about how LookupTypes are used in these tables, see the GSUB table specification and the GPOS table specification.

item.shortDesc: ELSE found without IF
item.problem: An ELSE was found that did not correspond with an IF.

item.shortDesc: ENDF beyond 64K of FDEF
item.problem: A function length cannot exceed 64K in size. An ENDF was found more than 64K away from its corresponding FDEF.

item.shortDesc: ENDF beyond 64K of IDEF
item.problem: A user-defined instruction cannot exceed 64K in size. An ENDF was found more than 64K away from its corresponding IDEF.

item.shortDesc: ENDF found without FDEF or IDEF
item.problem: An ENDF was found without its corresponding FDEF or IDEF.

item.shortDesc: IDEF exceeds max instruction defs in maxp
item.problem: The number of instructions defined exceeds value for maxInstructionDefs in maxp.

item.shortDesc: FDEF found within FDEF - ENDF pair
item.problem: A function cannot be defined within another function or user-defined instruction.

item.shortDesc: FDEF found within IDEF - ENDF pair
item.problem: A function cannot be defined within another function or user-defined instruction.

item.shortDesc: FDEF out of range
item.problem: Zero-based value for function number exceeds the maxp value for maxFunctionsDefs - 1.

item.shortDesc: Function definition space not defined
item.problem: The called function was not properly defined. Make sure function was defined in either the font program or the pre-program.

item.shortDesc: FDEF found without ENDF
item.problem: An FDEF was found that did not correspond with an ENDF.

item.shortDesc: Funit coordinate out of range must be -16384 .. 16383
item.problem: Font Unit values must be in the range of -16384 to 16383.

item.shortDesc: Function not defined
item.problem: The called function was not properly defined. Make sure function was defined in either the font program or the pre-program.

item.shortDesc: IDEF found within FDEF - ENDF pair
item.problem: A user-defined instruction cannot be defined within another user-defined instruction or function.

item.shortDesc: IDEF found within IDEF - ENDF pair
item.problem: A user-defined instruction cannot be defined within another user-defined instruction or function.

item.shortDesc: IDEF found without ENDF
item.problem: An IDEF was found that did not correspond with an ENDF.

item.shortDesc: IF found without corresponding EIF
item.problem: An IF was found that did not correspond with an EIF.

item.shortDesc: Instruction OpCode is to large. Must be between 0 and 255
item.problem: The instruction OpCode you are trying to define is too large. The OpCode is 8-bits in size, and can only have a value of 0-255.

item.shortDesc: Instruction already defined by rasterizer
item.problem: There is an attempt to create a user-defined instruction that is already defined by the rasterizer.

item.shortDesc: Invalid Instruction flag
item.problem: For the instructions MDRP, MIRP, ROUND, and NROUND, the value 3 has been used as distance type for engine characteristic compensation. For these instructions, two bits of the instruction flags are designated for the distance type for engine characteristic compensation. Valid values are 0 for Gray, 1 for Black and 2 for White.

item.shortDesc: Invalid Instruction
item.problem: Attempt to execute an instruction which is invalid and has not been defined.

item.shortDesc: Invalid maxZones in maxp table
item.problem: The value for maxZones in maxp must be either 1 or 2: 1 if you do not use the twilight zone, and 2 if you do.

item.shortDesc: Attempt to access stack element out of range
item.problem: Make sure the value for the index will not access a stack element which is either above the top of the stack or below the bottom of the stack. Stack index must be greater than or equal to 1.

item.shortDesc: Invalid zone
item.problem: Valid values for zone are: 0 or 1 if maxZones in maxp is 2; 1 if maxZones in maxp1 is 1.

item.shortDesc: ZP2 in IUP does not point to zone 1
item.problem: IUP operates on points in the glyph zone pointed to by ZP2. This zone should always be zone 1. IUP cannot operate on the twilight zone.

item.shortDesc: No twilight zone defined. Invalid zone
item.problem: There is an attempt to use the twilight zone when it does not exist because maxZones in maxp is 1. The value for maxZones should be set to 2 if the twilight zone is going to be used.

item.shortDesc: Jump before beginning of program or function
item.problem: There is an attempt to use one of the jump instructions to jump to an offset in the instruction stream which is before the beginning of the program or function.

item.shortDesc: Jump beyond 2 bytes past end of function or program
item.problem: There is an attempt to use one of the jump instructions to jump to an offset in the instruction stream which is more than 2 bytes beyond the end of the function or program.

item.shortDesc: Math overflow
item.problem: The result of either ADD, SUB, MUL, or DIV is an overflow. The result cannot fit into an F26Dot6 value.

item.shortDesc: Not called from pre-program
item.problem:
Make sure you only make this call from the pre-program.

FDEF and IDEF can only be called from the font program or pre-program. INSTCTRL[ ] can only be called from the pre-program.

item.shortDesc: Overflow Instruction Stream
item.problem: One of the PUSH instructions has tried to push data which is beyond the end of the instruction stream.

item.shortDesc: Point out of range
item.problem: Either the zero-based point value exceeds the larger of the maxp table values of maxPoints - 1 and maxCompositePoints - 1, or the zero-based point value exceeds value for the number of points in outline - 1, including phantom points.

item.shortDesc: Zone referenced in pre-program is not the twilight zone
item.problem: If you are operating in the pre-program, a zone referenced must be the twilight zone since the context does not include a particular glyph and there are no actual points.

item.shortDesc: Reference point used but not set
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: At least one reserved bit is set
item.problem: At least one reserved bit of the flags field is set. Make sure it is clear since it is reserved for future use.

item.shortDesc: RP1 and RP2 have the same position on the projection vector
item.problem: For the IP instruction, it is illegal if RP1 and RP2 have the same position on the projection vector.

item.shortDesc: Selector invalid
item.problem: The selector value is outside valid range.

item.shortDesc: Stack Overflow
item.problem: There is an attempt to PUSH more data on the stack than space will accommodate. Adjust maxStackElements field in the maxp table.

item.shortDesc: Stack Underflow
item.problem: There is an attempt to POP a value from below the bottom of the stack. Make sure the data you are popping from the stack has been pushed onto the stack.

item.shortDesc: Storage index out of range
item.problem: Zero-based storage index exceeds the maxp value for maxStorage - 1. Adjust maxp accordingly.

item.shortDesc: Storage location not written to
item.problem: The storage location has not been written to. This means that the data in the storage location is not valid.

item.shortDesc: Twilight zone point not set
item.problem: A twilight zone point has not been set and is not valid. Make sure it is set with an instruction like MDAP before it is used.

item.shortDesc: Value invalid should be 0 or 1
item.problem: If the selector for the INSTCTRL instruction is 1, then valid values for the value parameter are 0 or 1.

item.shortDesc: Value invalid should be 0 or 2
item.problem: If the selector for the INSTCTRL instruction is 2, then valid values for the value parameter are 0 or 2.

item.shortDesc: Value out of range
item.problem: The value is outside its value range.

item.shortDesc: Value exceeds capacity of 2 byte number
item.problem: The value is too big to fit into a 16-bit (2-byte) number.

item.shortDesc: Value exceeds capacity of 1 byte number
item.problem: The value is too big to fit into an 8-bit (1-byte) number.

item.shortDesc: Value too small
item.problem: The value is less than the smallest allowed value.

item.shortDesc: X and Y components of vector are invalid. X^2 + Y^2 != 0x4000^2
item.problem: Values to be put on the stack are based on normalized vector lengths and must be set such that (X^2 + Y^2) is 1. 0x4000 is the hex representation of 1 in 2.14 format.

item.shortDesc: X and Y components of vector are 0
item.problem: The X and Y components of a vector passed to SPVFS or SFVFS cannot be 0.

item.shortDesc: Zone not 0 nor 1
item.problem: The zone is set to something other than 0 or 1.

item.shortDesc: Could not perform rasterization
item.problem: Rasterization could not be performed because the head, maxp, or glyf table is missing.

item.shortDesc: Characters in a unicode range are present in the font, but not indicated in ulUnicodeRange fields
item.problem: Frequently, it is not necessary to cover the entire Unicode range for a font to be considered functional in that range. The font designer determines whether this font can be useful (or should be used) for the Unicode range noted.

item.shortDesc: The post name isn't in uniXXXX or uXXXXX format and there is no Adobe Glyph List entry
item.problem: PostScript character set glyph names should match those in the PostScript Reference Manual. Glyphs outside the PostScript character set may use a character string in the format of uniXXXX as their PostScript name. To learn more about PostScript names, see Adobe Glyph List.

item.shortDesc: The post name does not match the name in the Adobe Glyph List
item.problem: PostScript character set glyph names should match those in the PostScript Reference Manual. Glyphs outside the PostScript character set may use a character string in the format of uniXXXX as their PostScript name. To learn more about PostScript names, see Adobe Glyph List.

item.shortDesc: The glyphNameIndex array was not tested since version != 2
item.problem: This field is only used in Version 2.0 of the post table (for TrueType fonts to be used on Windows). Since the post table has a different version, tests of these fields were not performed.

item.shortDesc: The post name was not tested since version != 2
item.problem: This field is only used in Version 2.0 of the post table (for TrueType fonts to be used on Windows). Since the post table has a different version, tests of these fields were not performed.

item.shortDesc: The numberOfGlyphs field was not tested since version != 2
item.problem: This field is only used in Version 2.0 of the post table (for TrueType fonts to be used on Windows). Since the post table has a different version, tests of these fields were not performed.
