No problems were found during rasterization testing
Tables are not in optimal order
item.problem:
OpenType fonts with TrueType outlines are most efficiently utilized by Windows when the tables are ordered as follows (from first to last):
head, hhea, maxp, OS/2, hmtx, LTSH, VDMX, hdmx, cmap, fpgm, prep, cvt, loca, glyf, kern, name, post, gasp, PCLT, DSIG

The initial loading of an OpenType font containing CFF data will be more efficient if the following table ordering is used within the body of the font (from first to last):
head, hhea, maxp, OS/2, name, cmap, post, CFF, other tables (as convenient)

This efficiency results from the operating system being able to access commonly used information without having to move between 'pages' of data in memory. Therefore, the efficiency gained by Windows applies to implementations of the rasterizer on other operating systems that use a paging architecture.

To reorder the tables of a font, use the FastFont tool (available from Microsoft). You will need to create a text file containing table tags in the order in which you want them, and then reference this text file as a parameter of the FastFont tool. (The default order in which tables are placed by FastFont is antiquated.) Tables not included in the list above should be placed at the end of the table before the font is signed (and a DSIG table is appended as the last table in the font). If two tables are dependent on each other (like vhea/vmtx) then they should be placed next to each other.

item.shortDesc: Table is unnecessary
item.problem: Depending on the typeface and coverage of a font, certain tables are not necessary to have in the font file. For example, in a purely Latin (WinAnsi) font, the vhea (vertical header) and vmtx (vertical metrics) tables are not necessary.

item.shortDesc: Recommended table is missing
item.problem: Depending on the typeface and coverage of a font, certain tables are recommended for optimum quality. For example, the performance of a non-linear font is improved if the VDMX, LTSH, and hdmx tables are present (use the CacheTT tool to calculate these values and create these tables). Non-monospaced Latin fonts should have a kern table. A gasp table is necessary if a designer wants to influence the sizes at which grayscaling is used under Windows. A DSIG table containing a digital signature helps ensure the integrity of the font file. Etc.

item.shortDesc: The directory entry table offset is not a multiple of 4
item.problem:
All tables should be aligned to begin at offsets which are multiples of four bytes. While this is not required by the TrueType rasterizer, it does prevent ambiguous checksum calculations and greatly speeds table access on some processors.
All tables should be recorded in the table directory with their actual length. To ensure that checksums are calculated correctly, it is suggested that tables begin on LONG word boundries. Any extra space after a table (and before the next LONG word boundry) should be padded with zeros.

item.shortDesc: Non-zero pad bytes were found for the table
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: Cannot perform test due to an error in another table
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: Cannot perform test due to other errors in this table
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: Character code 240, the Apple logo, isn't mapped to missing glyph in cmap 1,0 (legal requirement for Microsoft fonts)
item.problem: Microsoft fonts developed for use on Apple platforms (platform 1, encoding 0) must map the Apple logo (character code 240) to the missing glyph in the cmap table.

item.shortDesc: Apple logo mapping test not performed, cmap 1,0 not present
item.problem: Because there is not an Apple-platform subtable present in the font (platform 1, encoding id 0), the mapping test for the Apple logo was not performed.

item.shortDesc: The table does not contain any Apple subtables
item.problem:
For Microsoft fonts, at least two subtables are required within the cmap table: Format 4 (Windows) and Format 0 (Macintosh) subtables.

Format 4 is a Windows subtable which uses platform id 3 and encoding id 1 if the font is a text face, and encoding id 0 if the font is a symbol font. This format supports two-byte glyph indices.

Format 0 is a Macintosh subtable and uses platform id 1 and encoding id 0. This format supports single-byte glyph indices.

item.shortDesc: The table does not contain any Microsoft subtables
item.problem:
For Microsoft fonts, at least two subtables are required within the cmap table: Format 4 (Windows) and Format 0 (Macintosh) subtables.

Format 4 is a Windows subtable which uses platform id 3 and encoding id 1 if the font is a text face, and encoding id 0 if the font is a symbol font. This format supports two-byte glyph indices.

Format 0 is a Macintosh subtable and uses platform id 1 and encoding id 0. This format supports single-byte glyph indices.

item.shortDesc: Character code 219, the euro character, is not mapped in cmap 1,0
item.problem: The Euro glyph is required for all Microsoft fonts. The glyph should be mapped to Unicode U+20AC, and Macintosh character code 219.

item.shortDesc: Character code U+20AC, the euro character, is not mapped in cmap 3,1
item.problem: The Euro glyph is required for all Microsoft fonts. The glyph should be mapped to Unicode: U+20AC, and Macintosh character code: x00DB

item.shortDesc: The format is 12, but the encoding id is not 10
item.problem: Fonts providing Unicode encoded UCS-4 character support for Win2000 and later need to have a format 4 subtable using platform 3, encoding 1, as well as have a format 12 subtable using platform 3, encoding 10.

item.shortDesc: Characters are mapped in the Unicode Private Use area
item.problem:
Characters are mapped to the Private Use Area. Microsoft recommends that use of the PUA is avoided. For Microsoft fonts, any alternate glyphs, OpenType glyphs, or unused glyphs should NOT be mapped in the Private Use Area. These glyphs should remain unmapped.

For legacy reasons, the 'fi' and 'fl' ligatures are the only glyphs that should be mapped in this area, as follows:

fi ligature
Unicode: U+FB01 and U+F001

fl ligature
Unicode: U+FB02 and U+F002

item.shortDesc: Format 14 tables not packed
item.problem: The region of non-default and default UVS tables following the Variation Selector records is not packed. This may indicated corrupted data

item.shortDesc: Two adjacent ranges have identical flags
item.problem: Two adjacent size ranges specified in the gasp table are using the same settings for grid fitting and grayscale rendering. Check that the gasp flag settings are correct for both ranges, or whether it may be possible to combine the two ranges into a single range.

item.shortDesc: Reserved bit is set to 1
item.problem: A composite glyph description contained in the glyf table has bit 4 of the flag field incorrectly set to 1. This bit should be set to 0.

item.shortDesc: The created time is zero
item.problem: The time the font was created should be a 64-bit integer that equals the number of seconds since midnight, January 1, 1904. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: The created time is an unlikely value
item.problem: The time the font was created should be a 64-bit integer that equals the number of seconds since midnight, January 1, 1904. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: Non-linear scaling flag (bit 4) is set, but hdmx table is not present
item.problem: Bit 4 of the flags field in the head table is set, indicating that the advance widths might not scale linearly (that is, hints applied to the glyphs might alter the advance widths). Regenerate this font.

item.shortDesc: Non-linear scaling flag (bit 4) is set, but LTSH table is not present
item.problem: Bit 4 of the flags field in the head table is set, indicating that the advance widths might not scale linearly (that is, hints applied to the glyphs might alter the advance widths). Regenerate this font.

item.shortDesc: The lowestRecPPEM value may be unreasonably large
item.problem: This value should indicate the smallest size (in pixels) at which the font is readable. The lowestRecPPEM value should be an indicator of the level at which the font is hinted. Use a head table editor to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: The lowestRecPPEM value may be unreasonably small
item.problem: This value should indicate the smallest size (in pixels) at which the font is readable. The lowestRecPPEM value should be an indicator of the level at which the font is hinted. This value is not required when bitmaps exist in the font for use at small sizes. Use a head table editor to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: The modified time is zero
item.problem: The time the font was modified should be a 64-bit integer that equals the number of seconds since midnight, January 1, 1904. Check to ensure that the tool you are using to edit the font is producing this value correctly.

item.shortDesc: The modified time is an unlikely value
item.problem: The time the font was modified should be a 64-bit integer that equals the number of seconds since midnight, January 1, 1904. Check to ensure that the tool you are using to edit the font is producing this value correctly.

item.shortDesc: The unitsPerEm is less than 64 which is in violation of the Apple spec
item.problem: The Apple specification for TrueType fonts specifies that the range of possible values for unitsPerEm is 64-16384, and should be a power of 2.

item.shortDesc: The unitsPerEm value is not a power of two
item.problem:
Microsoft and Apple recommend that the unitsPerEm value of the font is a power of 2. Such a value allows font clients to efficiently perform calculations involving division.

Microsoft considers a value of 2048 unitsPerEm to be ideal because it is a power of 2, a high enough value for good precision in rendering, and a low enough value to be processed efficiently.

To learn more about these recommendations, see the Hinting and Production Guidelines Specification.

item.shortDesc: fontRevision is not consistent with the font's version string
item.problem: The fontRevision value in the head table should be consistent with the version string in the name table. The 'major' numbers should match and the 'minor' numbers should match to the thousandths place (when rounded and zero-padded).

item.shortDesc: The advanceWidthMax, minLeftSideBearing, minRightSideBearing, and xMaxExtent fields can not be validated
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: Ascender should be less than or equal to head.yMax
item.problem: For the most consistent performance between platforms, the hhea.ascender value should be less than or equal to the head.yMax value.

item.shortDesc: Descender should be greater than or equal to head.yMin
item.problem: For the most consistent performance between platforms, the hhea.descender value should be greater than or equal to the head.yMin value.

item.shortDesc: LineGap value is less than 0 (unlikely value)
item.problem: For the most consistent performance between platforms, the linegap value should indicate the difference between (winascent + windescent, lineheight used by Windows) and (hhea.ascender + (-hhea.descender), lineheight used by Apple). This is not an 'interline gap' value.

item.shortDesc: The LineGap value is less than the recommended value
item.problem: For the most consistent performance between platforms, the linegap value should indicate the difference between (winascent + windescent, lineheight used by Windows) and (hhea.ascender + (-hhea.descender), lineheight used by Apple). This is not an 'interline gap' value.

item.shortDesc: Ascender is different than OS/2.usWinAscent. Different line heights on Windows and Apple
item.problem: For the most consistent performance between platforms, the hhea.Ascender value (used by Apple) should be the same as the OS/2.usWinAscent value (used by Windows).

item.shortDesc: Descender is different than OS/2.usWinDescent. Different line heights on Windows and Apple
item.problem: For the most consistent performance between platforms, the hhea.Descender value (used by Apple) should be the same as the OS/2.usWinDescent value (used by Windows).

item.shortDesc: The leftSideBearing is greater than the advance width (unlikely value)
item.problem:
Most glyphs have an advance width that equals the following:

aw = lsb + width of outline + rsb. [the width of the outline being max x coordinate of outline data - min x coordinate of outline data).

However, there are cases where placement of a glyph does not cause the 'penpoint' to be advanced (as with some combining marks, or scripts that require diacritics that are separate from composite glyphs). In these cases, the leftSideBearing may be greater than the advance width.

item.shortDesc: The subtable's searchRange, entrySelector, and rangeShift fields cannot be validated
item.problem: The values of the fields noted cannot be calculated because the npairs field is set to 0. The npairs field should indicate the number of kerning pairs in the table. Recreate the kern table using a kern table editing tool.

item.shortDesc: Loca references a glyf entry which length is not a multiple of 4
item.problem: The local offsets to glyph data should be long-aligned, i.e., multiples of 4. Offsets which are not long-aligned may degrade the performance of some processors. Ensure that the outline editing tool you are using is creating the glyf table properly.

item.shortDesc: Glyf table is partially unreferenced by loca table
item.problem: There is data in the glyf table that is not referenced via offsets in the loca table. Remove the extra glyph data, or recreate the loca table.

item.shortDesc: The LTSH yPel value is zero
item.problem: The yPel value of the LTSH table records the ppem for each glyph at which the scaling becomes linear, despite instructions effecting the advance width. At and above the recorded threshold size, the glyph must remain linear in its scaling. The proper yPel value for glyphs that scale linearly at all sizes is '1' (at 1 ppem and above the glyph scales linearly). Use a tool such as CacheTT, available from Microsoft, to regenerate the LTSH table with correct values.

item.shortDesc: The subfamily string is inconsistent with the style of the font
item.problem: This warning is generated when there is an inconsistency between the contents of the subfamily string in the name table and the way the bold/italic bits are set in the fsSelection field of the OS/2 table. Only bold and italic styling is considered. For example, if the bold bit is set, the subfamily string should read 'Bold'. If the bold bit is not set, the subfamily string should read 'Regular'. To learn more about the fsSelection field in the OS/2 table, see <A TARGET="top" HREF="http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink?LinkID=10384">the OS/2 table specification</ A>.

item.shortDesc: The MS version string doesn't match the Mac version string
item.problem: The version string in the name table should exist for both platforms and should have the same value.

item.shortDesc: The 3,1 version string doesn't match the 3,10 version string
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: The copyright strings are inconsistent
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: The description strings are inconsistent
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: The trademark strings are inconsistent
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: A CodePage bit is clear in ulCodePageRange, but the font contains all of the printable characters from that codepage
item.problem: A codepage supported by this font is not represented in the codepage bit settings of the OS/2 table. Although the font may still be functional and valid, this warning may indicate an oversight on the part of the font designer, or a problem with the font development tool. Alternately, designers may choose not to claim codepage support if the additional characters are for special purposes and are not intended for general use at different sizes or at different resolutions.

item.shortDesc: A CodePage bit is set in ulCodePageRange, but the font is missing some of the printable characters from that codepage
item.problem: If a bit is set (1) indicating codepage coverage, then font clients will consider the font fully functional for that codepage. Although a font designer may choose to set a codepage bit if the font is 'substantially' functional for a codepage, this may cause problems to operating systems or applications expecting full codepage coverage. Font designers should select character sets that support fully functional code pages, if at all possible.

item.shortDesc: The fsSelection bold bit is set, but is inconsistent with the usWeightClass value
item.problem:
This warning is generated when there is an inconsistency between the usWeightClass field in the OS/2 table and the way the bold bit is set in the fsSelection field of the OS/2 table. If an application is choosing fonts based on weight class values, this font may not be enumerated properly.

If the bold bit is set, the Font Validator expects to find a usWeightClass value of at least 500 (400 being considered 'Regular').

item.shortDesc: The xAvgCharWidth field can not be validated
item.problem: This value cannot be validated because width data for glyphs is not available. This is either because the hmtx table, a required table, is corrupted or missing. Regenerate a new version of the font containing a valid hmtx table.

item.shortDesc: PANOSE(tm) is undefined. Font mapping may not work properly
item.problem: PANOSE(tm) values are important for font clients that must substitute a font when a specified font is not available. PANOSE values should be carefully assigned to ensure adequate font mapping. PANOSE values are fully described in the reference noted below.

item.shortDesc: The version number is valid, but less than 3
item.problem: The version number of the OS/2 table identifies the content and layout of the table. The version number used currently is three (3). Versions zero (0, TrueType rev 1.5), one (1, TrueType rev 1.66), and two (2, OpenType rev 1.2) have been used previously. Incrementing the version number of the table will require that values stored in the table be changed to conform to the new version.

item.shortDesc: yStrikeoutPosition has unlikely value
item.problem: This field should specify the position of the top of the strikeout stroke relative to the baseline in font design units. Positive values represent distances above the baseline, while negative values represent distances below the baseline (although this would be an unlikely location for strikeout positioning). A value of zero falls directly on the baseline, while a value of one falls one pel above the baseline. The value of the strikeout position should not interfere with the recognition of standard characters, and therefore not line up with crossbars in a font. For a Roman font with a 2048 em square, 460 is suggested.

item.shortDesc: yStrikeoutSize has unlikely value
item.problem: This field should specify the width of the strikeout stroke in font design units. This field should normally be the width of the em dash for the current font. If the size is one, the strikeout line will be the line represented by the strikeout position field. If the value is two, the strikeout line will be the line represented by the strikeout position and the line immediately above the strikeout position. For a roman font with a 2048 em square, 102 is suggested.

item.shortDesc: ySubscriptXSize has unlikely value
item.problem: This value, measured in Funits, should represent the horizontal size for subscripts for this font, as recommended by the font designer. This value can be used by clients for simulating or substituting subscript glyphs if true subscript glyphs are not available in the font. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: ySubscriptYOffset is less than zero which is an unlikely value
item.problem: This value, measured in Funits, should represent the horizontal offset for subscript characters for this font, as recommended by the font designer. The offset is measured from the character origin of the font to the character origin of the subscript character. For upright characters, this value is usually zero. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: ySubscriptYSize has unlikely value
item.problem: This value, measured in Funits, should represent the vertical size for subscripts for this font, as recommended by the font designer. This value can be used by clients for simulating or substituting subscript glyphs if true subscript glyphs are not available in the font. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: ySuperscriptXSize has unlikely value
item.problem: This value, measured in Funits, should represent the horizontal size for superscripts for this font, as recommended by the font designer. This value can be used by clients for simulating or substituting superscript glyphs if true superscript glyphs are not available in the font. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: ySuperscriptYOffset is less than zero which is an unlikely value
item.problem: This value, measured in Funits, should represent the vertical offset for superscript characters for this font, as recommended by the font designer. The offset is measured from the character baseline to the superscript character's baseline. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: ySuperscriptYSize has unlikely value
item.problem: This value, measured in Funits, should represent the vertical size for superscripts for this font, as recommended by the font designer. This value can be used by clients for simulating or substituting superscript glyphs if true superscript glyphs are not available in the font. Use a table editing tool to correct this value.

item.shortDesc: The usWeightClass is inconsistent with the PANOSE weight value
item.problem: Use a table editing tool to correct the usWeightClass value and/or the PANOSE value so that they correspond.

item.shortDesc: The value of sTypoAscender minus sTypoDescender is greater than unitsPerEm
item.problem: The sTypoAscender value is used to determine the optimum offset from the top of a text frame to the first baseline. The sTypoDescender value is used to determine the optimum offset from the last baseline to the bottom of the text frame. The sTypoDescender value should be greater than zero, and the value of (sTypoAscender - sTypoDescender) is recommended to equal one em. To learn more about this value, see the Recommendations for OpenType Fonts.

item.shortDesc: The italicAngle value is unlikely
item.problem: The italic angle value is measured in degrees, counter-clockwise from the vertical. Zero is the value for upright text. Negative values are used for text that leans to the right (forward for left-to-right writing). This value should be in agreement with the caretSlopeRise and caretSlopeRun values in the hhea table.

item.shortDesc: The underlinePosition value is less than hhea.Descender
item.problem: The underlinePosition value in the post table is the suggested distance from the top of the underline to the baseline (negative values indicate below baseline). Typically, underlines are not positioned beyond the lowest descender in the font.

item.shortDesc: The underlineThickness value is unlikely
item.problem: The thickness of the underline for the font, as specified in the post table, is either less than zero or is greater than 1/2 the unitsPerEm. Correct this value using a table editing tool.

item.shortDesc: The version number is 0x00025000, which is valid but deprecated
item.problem: Version 2.5 of the post table was deprecated by Apple in February, 2000, with the release of version 1.3 of the OpenType specification.

item.shortDesc: The device table StartSize is unusually large
item.problem: The device table defines single pixel adjustments for specified font sizes (in ppem). Since 16384 is the largest unitsPerEm value allowed for OpenType fonts, 16384 is the largest ppem size that can be specified as a starting or ending size in the device table. To learn more about allowable and recommended ppem values, see the head table specification and the Hinting and Production Guidelines Specification.

item.shortDesc: The device table EndSize is unusually large
item.problem: The device table defines single pixel adjustments for specified font sizes (in ppem). Since 16384 is the largest unitsPerEm value allowed for OpenType fonts, 16384 is the largest ppem size that can be specified as a starting or ending size in the device table. To learn more about allowable and recommended ppem values, see the head table specification and the Hinting and Production Guidelines Specification.

item.shortDesc: The FeatureRecord tag is valid, but unregistered
item.problem: Microsoft maintains a registry of supported feature and language tags. The registry establishes conventions for naming and using these tags. Registered tags have a specific meaning and convey precise information to developers and text-processing clients of OpenType Layout. Microsoft encourages font developers to use registered tags to assure compatibility and ease of use across fonts, applications, and operating systems.

item.shortDesc: Instruction is only valid on the Apple platform
item.problem: This warning indicates that the instruction used is not valid under Windows. The instruction is only valid on Apple platforms. Please consult Apple documentation to find out for which versions of the Mac OS the instruction is valid.

item.shortDesc: CALL to zero length function
item.problem: A call to a zero length function should be avoided because it wastes an instruction (although it is legal).

item.shortDesc: Call to zero length user defined instruction
item.problem: A call to a zero length user-defined instruction should be avoided because it wastes an instruction (although it is legal).

item.shortDesc: DEBUG found which should not be found in production code
item.problem: Remove all DEBUG statements before shipping this font.

item.shortDesc: Repeated executions in glyph programs can have unexpected results
item.problem: The DELTAC instruction changes the value of CVT entries. If this is executed in a glyph program, every time that glyph is hinted the CVT entry is changed. These changes will accumulate and cause a result that the hinter might not have expected.

item.shortDesc: High point is less than low point
item.problem: If the value for the high point is less than the low point, the instruction will do nothing.

item.shortDesc: Jump offset zero
item.problem: The jump offset is zero which means that execution will jump back to this jump instruction.

item.shortDesc: Loop variable not 1 at end of program. This means it was set but not used
item.problem: At the end of the execution of the instructions for a glyph, the loop variable was not 1, which means that it was set and not used by any other instructions. In this case, the SLOOP instruction is wasted.

item.shortDesc: Value for count is less than 1. Function will not be called
item.problem: The 'value for count' is the number of times LOOPCALL will call the function. In the LOOPCALL instruction, if the value for count is less than 1, the function will not be called.

item.shortDesc: Window 95 and Windows 3.1 always return 12
item.problem: Windows 95 and Windows 3.1 will always return 12 in response to the MPS instruction. This is a side effect of the way the TrueType rasterizer was integrated into Windows.

item.shortDesc: Projection and freedom vectors at or near perpendicular
item.problem: The current projection and freedom vectors are at or near perpendicular. This could cause points to move in an unexpected manner.

item.shortDesc: Point not touched
item.problem: Untouching a point that is not touched. This is a waste of an instruction.

item.shortDesc: Function no longer needed because of dropped support of AA
item.problem: ERROR: Required field missing

item.shortDesc: Loca references a zero-length entry in the glyf table
item.problem: This message may indicate that there are multiple zero-length glyphs located at the end of the glyf table. If so, remove the extra empty glyphs.

item.shortDesc: maxSizeOfInstructions via method #1
item.problem:
The maxSizeOfInstructions field may be calculated by two methods, the first being preferred:
  1. The maximum instruction size of any glyph, taking into account only the instructions in the glyf table.
  2. The same as method #1, plus the size of the prep table plus the size of the fpgm table.

This info message indicates that maxSizeOfInstructions computed via method #1.

item.shortDesc: maxSizeOfInstructions via method #2
item.problem:
The maxSizeOfInstructions field may be calculated by two methods, the first being preferred:
  1. The maximum instruction size of any glyph, taking into account only the instructions in the glyf table.
  2. The same as method #1, plus the size of the prep table plus the size of the fpgm table.

This info message indicates that maxSizeOfInstructions computed via method #2.

item.shortDesc: maxSizeOfInstructions computation not via either approved method
item.problem:
The maxSizeOfInstructions field may be calculated by two methods, the first being preferred:
  1. The maximum instruction size of any glyph, taking into account only the instructions in the glyf table.
  2. The same as method #1, plus the size of the prep table plus the size of the fpgm table.

A font showing this warning has maxSizeOfInstructions that is larger than the value calculated by method #1, but not equal to the value calculated by method #2. (Note that a maxSizeOfInstructions value smaller than that calculated via method #1 is an error.)

The fact that the maxSizeOfInstructions value does not match the value computed by either method may indicate some other problem in the font.

item.specLink: WARNING: Rasterization for fonts with PostScript outlines not implemented yet.
item.shortDesc: Could not perform rasterization
item.problem: Rasterization could not be performed because the font file has PostScript outlines.

item.shortDesc: The VDMX data doesn't match the data calculated by the rasterizer
item.problem: The VDMX data does not match the value calculated by the current version of the rasterizer. This data may not match if glyphs have been updated but the VDMX table has not been recalculated (using a tool such as Microsoft's CacheTT). The problem may also occur if the VDMX table was generated using a previous version of the rasterizer, or another tool that performs the calculations differently. To correct the data, use the latest version of CacheTT to calculate the cached values using the current rasterizer. However, you may not want to change these values if there are concerns about the way text in legacy documents might reflow.
